00006 // NSString has a method for decoding percent escapes but none for encoding
00007 // So, here they are:
00008 - (NSString*)encodePercentEscapesPerRFC2396 ;
00009 - (NSString*)encodePercentEscapesStrictlyPerRFC2396 ;
00010 // Decodes any existing percent escapes which should not be encoded per RFC 2396 sec. 2.4.3
00011 // Encodes any characters which should be encoded per RFC 2396 sec. 2.4.3.
00012 - (NSString*)encodePercentEscapesPerRFC2396ButNot:(NSString*)butNot butAlso:(NSString*)butAlso ;
00013 
00014 // butNot and/or butAlso may be nil
00015 // I did an experiment to find out which ASCII characters are encoded,
00016 // by encoding a string with all the nonalphanumeric characters available on the
00017 // Macintosh keyboard, with and without the shift key down.  There were fourteen:
00018 //       ` # % ^ [ ] { } \ | " < >
00019 // You only see thirteen because the fourtheenth one is the space character, " ".
00020 // This agrees with the lists of "space" "delims" and "unwise" in  by RFC 2396 sec. 2.4.3
00021 // Also, I found that all of the non-ASCII characters available on the Macintosh 
00022 // keyboard by using option or shift+option are also encoded.  Some of these have
00023 // two bytes of unicode to encode, for example %C2%A4 for 0xC2A4
00024 
00033 + stringWithQueryDictionary:(NSDictionary*)dictionary ;

00036  Performing test in implementation to see if I can use that instead of this.
00037  */
00038 - (NSString*)decodeAllPercentEscapes ;
